(52)), the recommendations of which are summarised in the last paragraph as follows:- previous reference: (l) The Temporary Commercial Agreement ofCabinet 30 16th April, 1930, should be denouncedjf(S2) Con- forthwith by means of a notice to bellusion 5.) given under Article 7 to terminate that o Agreement on the expiration of sixk months from the date of the notice.33(5-2-;(2) The notice should be one to terminate the Agreement at the end of six months,without any addition or- qualification.The representatives of His Majesty7sGovernment concerned with any negotia-tions for a fresh Agreement shouldhave discretion to concede a temporaryextension of the Agreement if this isin our interests. The fact that thisdiscretion has been given should,however, be kept secret.(3) The negotiation of a fresh Anglo-russian trade Agreement is in the best interestsof the country, and the undertaking of negotiations 'should be authorised if andwhen . opportunity: offers .(4) If the Cabinet accept our recommendationregarding the denunciation of the Agree-ment, it will then be open to the Cabinetto determine their policy in regard tothe prohibition or restriction of theimport of Rvissian wheat into the UnitedKingdom. We note that if the cabinet decide in favour of a,.policy of prohibi-tion or restriction, the Ottawa committee recommend that no announcement of that policy should be made prior to the ottawa conference, and we concur in this recom-mendation.(5) It is doubtful whether denunciation ofthe Commercial Agreement will have anysubstantial effect as regards such aspectsof Anglo-Soviet relations as propaganda,though with a free hand In trade matterswe might be able,by threats of economic pressure, to induce the Soviet Governmentto exercise more effective control overorganisations such as the Third Inter-national. In any case we are agreed thatdenunciation of the Agreement cannot worsenthe position as -regards the propagandaissue.In addition' to the above Report, which had been -before them at the previous Meeting, the Cabinet had under consideration a Memorandum by the Presidentof the Board of Trade (CP.-190 (32)), prepared at their request, containingfigures as to Trade with Russia. In this memorandum it was pointed out that in April, for the first time,exports to Russia were greater than imports; thatduring the first four months of last year importsexceeded exports by 5,017,000, and that this excesswas reduced to 517,000 for the first four monthsof this year. The reduction in the visible adverse balance was due both to a diminution in the value ofimports and to an increase in the value of domesticexports.Considerable discussion took"place on the abovedocuments. The issue was narrowed down to thequestion as to whether the present moment wasopportune for carrying out the Committee's recommend-ations . This turned, to a considerable extent on thequestion of whether notice to terminate the agreement at the end of six months would exercise an adverse effect on our exports to Russia or not. If theresults were adverse, the effect on unemployment would be serious, as illustrated by estimates givento the Cabinet by the Minister of Labour (Appendix).more particularly at the present time when unemploy-ment was Increasing. Particulars were given ofimportant contracts (e,g., for machine tools, ironand steel plates, and herrings) which are at presentthe subject of negotiation with the Russian SovietGovernment. The Committee were understood to hold the view that the effect on trade would not be detrimental. A suggestion was made that instead ofgiving notice to terminate the Trade agreement it would be better, in the circumstances, to approach the Russian Government, through their Ambassador,explain our difficulties and endeavour to negotiate an Agreement by consent. It was reported, however,that the Committee had considered this proposal andhad come to the conclusion, in view of previous experience in negotiations with the Soviet Govern-ment, that we should be much more likely to reach a satisfactory new arrangement if notice were givento terminate the present Trade Agreement.The Secretary of State for War was opposed toall Trade Agreements with Soviet Russia.The Prime;Minister suggested that the report should be referred back to the Committee to reconsiderits recommendations in the light of.the cabinet discussion.-The question was then raised as to whether therecommendations of the Committee on matters otherthan the Trade Agreement would also be referred back.As time did not permit the completion of thediscussion, it was adjourned; but at the conclusionof the Meeting the Prime Minister warned hiscolleagues of a serious leakage which had occurredimmediately after a previous Cabinet decisionaffecting Russia, and asked that every possibleprecaution should be taken within Departments toprevent a repetition of this, -CIVIL SERVICEREMUNERATION.(previous reference reference e:Cabinet 28(38), Con-clusion 15.)6.
